My first Spigot Plugin

by Adam B â€¢ 13/08/2022

New horizons.

Soâ€¦ Step one I guess?

Step 1 Installing plugins

When deciding that I wanted to tinker with Minecraft Plugins in java I first had to decide what IDE to use.

I chose IntelliJ because it is free for personal use, has a nice dark theme, and has a huge library of plugins. Speaking of plugins, to assist me on my journey I downloaded the following;

  • Atom Material Icons
  • Material Theme UI
  • Minecraft Development
  • Nyan Progress Bar (Because why not?)

Step 2 Creating A Project

Using the Minecraft Development plugin I can generate a project with everything pre-setup for working with Spigot. Here I select the Spigot Plugin option so the plugin will use that specific API.

Here I learned that itâ€™s best practice to use your TLD then website name as your GroupId and the pluginâ€™s name as the ArtifactID so I entered dev.lerndmina & exampleplugin. I also decided to use Maven as my build tool because the majority of tutorials use mavenâ€¦

Next I filled out some of the required and optional plugin settings paying special attention ot the Minecraft Version setting as that will determine what API version I will need to refrence when creating my plugin.

The only thing left was to give my project a local name and weâ€™re done!

Ahh. The glorious main class!

Now we need to set up the server to test this all on.

Step 3 Setting Up A Test Server

I like to run my testing servers on paper because itâ€™s fast and stable. So letâ€™s head on over to papermc.io and download the version we set earlier in the plugin settings. In this case itâ€™s 1.19.

Next weâ€™ll create a folder to house our Minecraft Server and move the server jar file into it, keep a note of the name of the jar file as weâ€™ll need it later.

Coming back to intellij navigate to;
File > Project Structure > Artifacts > âž• > JAR > From Modules With Dependencies...

Next we will type in the path to the Main Class which in this case is dev.lerndmina.exampleplugin.ExamplePlugin and click OK. The only other thing we need to change here is the Output directory. Set this to the plugins folder inside your Minecraft Server folder.

Alright, great!
Next we will add the settings which will make IntelliJ run the server for us so we only have to click one button to both build and run the plugin, handy right? Click on your currently listed build config and click edit configurations. Hereâ€™s a handy little image to explain.

Create a new Jar Application by clicking âž• > ðŸ“¦ Jar Application then give it a name.

psst, just follow the stuff in the image & customise to your needs

After that go to the before launch section and click the âž•. Add the build artifact task we created earlier.

Poof! Now with one button we can build our plugin and spin up a server to test it on!
